creator: 陳亮
title: ATtiny85 Ring Watch
description: This project describes how to build a functional ATtiny85 Ring Watch, a wearable gadget that displays time on a small OLED screen. It utilizes an ATtiny85 microcontroller, a CR1220 battery, and a custom-made ring body.
steps: Prepare the necessary materials including the ATtiny85 microcontroller, ISP programmer, CR1220 battery, SSD1306 OLED screen, and other components.
Setup the Arduino environment with ATtiny85, EEPROM, and TinyWireM support by downloading required libraries and making necessary modifications to the TinyWireM library.
Download the latest source code for the ATtinyWatch project from the provided GitHub repository.
Create the watch body using 3D printing or woodworking based on the provided Sketchup and STL files.
Solder the MCU to a SOP8 to DIP8 board for easier soldering and reprogramming.
Create a tailor-made button board using resistors to allow three buttons to be read using a single analog pin on the ATtiny85.
Solder the circuit together by connecting the MCU, OLED screen, button panel, and battery holder using coated copper wires. Use sandpaper to remove coating from the middle connect point.
Create a tailor-made battery holder using a thin metal plate and coated copper wire.
Program the ATtiny85 microcontroller using the ISP programmer and Arduino IDE, selecting the appropriate board and clock settings. Flash the ATtinyWatch.ino sketch to the microcontroller.

Debug the screen by pressing the up or down button while no date/time field is selected to enter a debug screen that displays Watch Dog Timer interrupt count, Auto tuned value, Calibrated battery level, ATtiny85 internal temperature.

Calibrate the time by pressing the set button to switch between date and time fields and adjust the values using the up and down buttons. The micro-second per WDT interrupt value will be auto tuned for each set time operation that over 1 hour interval

Calibrate the voltage reference by commenting/uncommenting certain lines in the WDT_time.h file and then programming it into the watch and adjusting values based on DEBUG_SCREEN_V and MULTI_METER_VOLTAGE.
Calibrate the temperature reference in WDT_time.h and then programming it into the watch and adjusting values based on DEBUG_SCREEN_T_1, TEMPERATURE_1, DEBUG_SCREEN_T_2 and TEMPERATURE_2
Assemble the watch by slotting the OLED screen into the pit and placing all components in their designated positions.
Secure the assembly by screwing the M2 screws into the ring body.
Create a transparent cover using a PET plastic plate, cut it to size, and attach it to the ring body using double-sided adhesive tape.
Enjoy your newly created ATtiny85 Ring Watch!
